Chapter 37, Part 2: MahÄmegha, Increasing and Expanding
The Buddha said:
Good sons!
Do not speak thus!
The body of the TathÄgata's transformed beings is called the transformation body.
World-Honored One!
What is the meaning of this?
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, abiding in this samÄdhi one attains the Dharma body. Why is it then said to be a transformation body?
If the TathÄgata's Dharma body transforms into a body that consumes various foods, why is this body not false?
As for the true Dharma body, how can it further transform into a body that consumes various foods?
If it transforms into a body that consumes food, this meaning is not correct.
The Buddha said:
Stop, stop!
Do not speak thus!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who abides in this samÄdhi, if there is a transformed body, is called an illusory body.
World-Honored One!
Why is it upside-down?
Why is it called a body when it is not a body?
That which has no substance is called an illusion;
If it is an illusory body, how can it not deceive sentient beings?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Do not view it like this!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwelling in this samÄdhi have no dwelling body.
Although they have no dwelling body, they are like a medicinal tree king, like grasses, trees, tiles, and pebbles.
My body is also like this.
Why is it so?
My body has no self, no possessions, no life, no speech, no mind, no reality, and no aggregates, sense bases, or elements.
It is like a medicinal tree that can cure all the illnesses and sufferings of sentient beings.
My body is also like this, eliminating the immeasurable illnesses and sufferings of sentient beings.
Why is it so?
Because the body is like an illusion.
Furthermore, good man!
It is like a medicinal tree that never gives rise to the thought:
'Take the leaves, not the branches.'
The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is also like this, never giving rise to the thought:
'Take the hands, not the feet.'
Why is this?
Because of the power of this samÄdhi, he is also able to eliminate and eradicate all sentient beings' illnesses of greed, anger, and delusion.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who abides in this samÄdhi has no inner body, no outer body, no inner and outer body, and no body subject to death and rebirth. He attains the body of immortality;
because of the body of immortality, he is able to eliminate sentient beings' illnesses of greed, anger, and delusion.
Furthermore, good man!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who abides in this samÄdhi creates a transformed body to eliminate all evils, birds, beasts, and the three evil destinies, just like a medicinal tree.
If there are people who say:
'The evil birds and beasts encounter the bodhisattva's body and reach the three evil destinies,'
this is impossible.
If one says:
'Abandoning the body and being reborn in the human and heavenly realms to see the Buddhas,' this is possible.
Furthermore, good man!
If one says:
'The four assemblies dwelling in this samÄdhi will then be able to draw near to immeasurable Buddhas,'
this is also possible.
Furthermore, good man!
If bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs wish to cultivate this samÄdhi, they should first contemplate:
'The TathÄgata is eternally abiding and unchanging;
The Buddha-Dharma does not perish, and there is none who ultimately enters nirvÄá¹‡a.'
They should further think:
'The various necessities of all sentient beings I shall provide, whether feet, hands, head, or eyes, for the sake of the true Dharma, I shall give up all that I have.
When giving, I shall rejoice, and after giving, I shall have no regrets.
Why is this?
This body of mine is like a medicinal tree.
If one is able to give rise to this single thought of contemplation, know that before long one will attain this samÄdhi.
Moreover, good man!
It is like a swift horse with a long tail.
On the fifteenth day of the fortnightly confession, in the great ocean, it neighs three times, saying:ğŸ”½'Who wishes to cross the ocean?
Who wishes to cross the ocean?'
If there are people who ride on its back, or grasp its tail, neck, head, or feet, they will all reach the other shore of the great ocean.

This Great Cloud SÅ«tra is also like this. If there are people who are able to uphold, recite, explain, and write even a single line or a single syllable, all will cross to the other shore of the three evil destinies and forever attain liberation.
Moreover, good man!

Bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs who hear the name of this samÄdhi will be born again and again always as a wheel-turning sage king, Åšakra, or BrahmÄ, and will never regress, always able to draw near to the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saá¹…gha.
In the mind of enlightenment, they will be firm and unmoving, not abandoning the MahÄyÄna vaipulya sÅ«tras.
World-Honored One!
How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abide in this samÄdhi and see the true reality of all dharmas?
The Buddha said:
Good man!

If one who has accomplished this samÄdhi sees the TathÄgata as impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity, and as finally entering nirvÄá¹‡a, then it cannot be called seeing the true reality;
If one sees the TathÄgata as permanent, blissful, having a self, and pure, and as never finally entering nirvÄá¹‡a, then this can be called seeing the true reality.
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said:
'If one sees the TathÄgata as being constant, blissful, self, and pure, what does that mean?'
Good man!
Constant, blissful, self, and pure are precisely the true nature of the TathÄgata.
World-Honored One!
If it is so, then all ordinary beings would also attain such true nature.
Why is it so?
Because ordinary beings also conceive of constant, blissful, self, and pure.
Good man!

You should not speak like this now. I say that only bodhisattvas who possess this samÄdhi can see constant, blissful, self, and pure, not that ordinary beings see constant, blissful, self, and pure in a deluded and inverted manner.
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said:

'If one sees all dharmas as being impermanent, suffering, non-self, and impure, then one sees the superior path and the inferior path, attains the fruit of stream-entry, and up to attaining supreme perfect enlightenment;
If one sees all dharmas as permanent, blissful, self, and pure, then one will not be able to attain the fruit of stream-entry, up to unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.
Why did the World-Honored One say:
'After a bodhisattva has accomplished this samÄdhi, he will then be able to see permanence, bliss, self, and purity?'
Moreover, as the Buddha said:
'True liberation is like empty space. Such liberation is nirvÄá¹‡a.'
Why did the TathÄgata say:

'NirvÄá¹‡a is permanent, blissful, self, and pure. All sentient beings are also like empty space, like the moon in water, like an illusion, a plantain tree, clouds, and lightning. They have no nature or characteristics, cannot abide for a moment, are like drawing water, and immediately merge with the drawing.

Seeing that cognition is impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity, seeing such characteristics is called true seeing. One who truly sees will attain the fruit of stream-entry, up to unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.'
How can the TathÄgata say:
'The bodhisattva who accomplishes this samÄdhi can then see permanence, bliss, self, and purity?'
As the Buddha said before:

'The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, view all dharmas as impermanent, without bliss, without self, and impure, without life, a person, or sentient beings, empty and nonexistent. This is called the true nature of all dharmas.'
Now he says again:
'Seeing all dharmas as permanent, blissful, self, and pure.' What is the meaning of this?
Good man!
Stop, stop!
Do not speak thus!
Good man!

If a bodhisattva accomplishes and is endowed with this samÄdhi, then he does not again unite with or not unite with dharmas. Therefore, he is called a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who guards the precepts and cultivates samÄdhi. He does not see the characteristics of annihilation or permanence in dharmas. Because he does not see annihilation, he does not give rise to joy. Because he does not see permanence, he does not give rise to sorrow. He knows the seal of the Dharma, but does not guard the precepts, and is also not called one who cultivates samÄdhi.

The TathÄgata is not attached to guarding the precepts or violating the precepts, permanence or impermanence, enlightenment or non-enlightenment, action or non-action, purity or impurity, emptiness or non-emptiness, precepts or non-precepts, knowledge or non-knowledge, name or non-name, grasping or non-grasping, fear or non-fear, terror or non-terror, cause or non-cause, cessation or non-cessation, enlightenment or non-enlightenment, liberation or non-liberation, nirvÄá¹‡a or non-nirvÄá¹‡a.
All dharmas are without fear. For the sake of liberation, one upholds the precepts and cultivates samÄdhi.

All dharmas are without decline. The bodhisattva, knowing this, delights in his mind and cultivates this samÄdhi. For the sake of sentient beings, he expounds that the Buddha TathÄgata is eternally abiding and unchanging, and that the true Dharma does not perish. Therefore, he upholds the precepts and cultivates samÄdhi.
Furthermore, good man!

If there are those who wish to attain such a samÄdhi, they should cultivate the notion of permanence, the notion of self, the notion of life, and the notion of person. Having cultivated these notions, they will then be able to accomplish and possess this samÄdhi. If it is said that they cannot attain it, that is not the case.
World-Honored One!
The TathÄgata sometimes speaks of impermanence, no bliss, no self, and impurity, and sometimes speaks of permanence, bliss, self, and purity. What is the meaning of this?
Good man!
The worldly path mistakenly sees all dharmas as permanent, blissful, self, and pure. Therefore, I say they are impermanent, selfless, suffering, and impure.
World-Honored One!
Are there also permanence, bliss, self, and purity in supramundane dharmas?
Good man!
If a bodhisattva abides in this samÄdhi and wishes to speak of self, he first speaks of five things.
What are the five?
First, grain seeds; second, tree seeds; third, nutritious flavors; fourth, hidden treasures; fifth, snake sloughs.
Good man!
As for grain seeds, when the sprouts, stems, leaves, and flowers are growing, they are called impermanent;
if the ripe grains are harvested and beings enjoy using them, they are called permanent.
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have not yet accomplished this samÄdhi, they are impermanent, selfless, suffering, and impure;
if they have already accomplished it, they can be called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
If one is unable to liberate all sentient beings, it is called impermanent, selfless, suffering, and impure;
If one is able to liberate [them], then it is called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
If one is unable to destroy all wrong views, it is called impermanent, suffering, selfless, and impure;
If one is able to destroy [them], then it is called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Because one is unable to permanently sever the afflictions, it is called impermanent, suffering, selfless, and impure;
If one is able to permanently sever [them], then it is called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Good man!
This is called the seed of grain.
Furthermore, good man!
Like the mango tree, before it bears fruit, it is called impermanent, not blissful, not self, and impure;
If the fruit ripens and sentient beings enjoy it, then it is called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have not yet accomplished this samÄdhi are called impermanent, selfless, suffering, and impure;
if they have accomplished it, they are then called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Because they are unable to liberate all sentient beings, they are called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and impure;
if they are able to liberate [beings], they are then called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Because they are unable to destroy all wrong views, they are called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and impure;
if they are able to destroy [wrong views], they are then called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Because they are unable to permanently sever the afflictions, they are called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and impure;
if they are able to permanently sever [the afflictions], they are then called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Good man!
this is called a tree seed.
Furthermore, good man!

It is like sesame seeds, before they become oil, they cannot eliminate the illnesses and sufferings of sentient beings, and are called impermanent, without happiness, without self, and without purity;
But once they become oil, they can eliminate the illnesses and sufferings of sentient beings, and are therefore called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have not yet accomplished this samÄdhi are called impermanent, without happiness, without self, and without purity;
But if they have accomplished it, they are then called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Because they are unable to liberate all sentient beings, they are called impermanent, without happiness, without self, and without purity;
But if they are able to liberate them, they are then called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Because they are unable to destroy all wrong views, they are called impermanent, without happiness, without self, and without purity;
But if they are able to destroy them, they are then called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Because they are unable to permanently sever the afflictions, they are called impermanent, without happiness, without self, and without purity;
If one can permanently sever them, then that is called permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Good man!
This is called the rich flavor.
Furthermore, good man!
It is like a treasure trove hidden in the ground, unable to benefit all beings, therefore it is called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity;
If it emerges from the ground and is used by beings for great benefit, then it is called permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have not accomplished this samÄdhi, they are called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity;
If they have accomplished it, then they are called permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Because they are unable to liberate all beings, they are called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity;
If they are able to liberate [beings], then they are called permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
If they are unable to destroy all wrong views, they are called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity;
If one can destroy them, then one can be called one who has attained permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Because one is unable to permanently sever the afflictions, one is called impermanent, selfless, without bliss, and without purity;
If one is able to permanently sever them, then one can be called one who has attained permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Good man!
This is called the treasure store.
Furthermore, good man!
Like a snake shedding its skin, before it sheds its skin, it is called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity;
If it has already shed its skin, then it can be called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have not yet attained accomplishment in this samÄdhi are called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity;
If they have already accomplished it, then they can be called one who has attained permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
If one is unable to liberate all sentient beings, one is called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity;
If one is able to liberate them, then one can be called one who has attained permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
If it cannot destroy all wrong views, it is called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and impure;
if it can destroy them, then it can be called permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Because it cannot permanently sever the afflictions, it is called impermanent, without bliss, without self, and impure;

if it can permanently sever them, then it can be called permanent, blissful, self, and pure, and it also severs the four kinds of doubts about the Buddha that sentient beings give rise to, regarding permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Good man!
This is called shedding the snake's skin.
Good man!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who abide in this samÄdhi expound the TathÄgata's permanence, bliss, self, and purity using these five things, and are able to speak of self, person, life, sentient beings, and human beings. Being able to see in this way is called right view.
World-Honored One!
The TathÄgata's explanation of these five things is not correct.
Why is it so?
The Tathagata always says in the sutras that all dharmas are impermanent.
As with the five things mentioned earlier, the cause is also impermanent, and the effect is also impermanent.
If it is so that the bodhisattva abides in this samadhi like the five things, then it should also be impermanent.
For this reason, all dharmas are not non-impermanent.
World-Honored One!
Where there is a cause, there must be a result; where there is a result, there must be a cause. All sentient beings and bodhisattvas are also like this;

where there is birth, there must be death; where there is death, there must be birth. If this is so, then permanence is also impermanence, and impermanence is also permanence. For this reason, all dharmas have two natures, permanence and impermanence;
one should not definitively say that worldly dharmas are impermanent and supramundane dharmas are permanent.
How can the Tathagata's true words give rise to such false speech?
Good man!
Why do you now wrap yourself up like a silkworm?
Good man!
If someone were to say:
'A handsome person is like a full moon;
A fragrant elephant is as white as a snow mountain.'
A person is not really the moon, and an elephant is not a snow mountain, but there is a slight resemblance, so it is used as a metaphor.
Good man!
The five things in the world are also like this, because they have a little permanence, so they are used as metaphors.
The buddhas, tathÄgatas, are truly incomparable, yet they use metaphors as metaphors.
World-Honored One!
If the TathÄgata is permanent, why did you also say in another sÅ«tra: 'Like a lamp going out, liberation is also like this'?
World-Honored One!
If the TathÄgata is permanent, how can he be extinguished?
If he is extinguished, how can you say he is permanent?
If the TathÄgata says he is both permanent and extinguished, are such words not false?
Moreover, as the Buddha said:
'All dharmas are like the moon in water.'
If all dharmas are permanent, why do you say they are like the moon in the water?
Good man!
I say conditioned dharmas are like the moon in the water, therefore I say some dharmas are permanent and some are impermanent.

If there are sentient beings who have not attained liberation, have not severed afflictions, have not severed names and forms, have not severed the notion of sentient beings, have not attained the dharma-mark, and have not cultivated such samÄdhis, they are called impermanent;

If there are sentient beings who have attained liberation, have permanently severed afflictions, names and forms, and the notion of sentient beings, have attained the dharma-mark, and cultivated samÄdhis, they are called permanent.
Therefore I say some dharmas are permanent and some are impermanent.
World-Honored One!
If that is so, why did the TathÄgata say:
'The Buddha's nirvÄá¹‡a is like the extinction of a lamp?'
Is the extinction of a lamp a metaphor for the extinction of the body, or a metaphor for the extinction of afflictions?ğŸ”½Good man!
It is like how the oil is inseparable from the lamp, and the lamp is inseparable from the oil.
Sentient beings are also like this. The body is inseparable from the afflictions, and the afflictions are inseparable from the body. How can you say they are extinguished?
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
If you see in this way, it is called right view.
Good man!
There are two kinds of bodies:
The first is the body of afflictions, and the second is the Dharma body.
The extinction of the body of afflictions is like the extinction of a lamp. Therefore, I say that the remaining dharmas are impermanent.
The Dharma body is without extinction, like empty space. Therefore, I say that the remaining dharmas are permanent.
Cutting off the vessel of afflictions is called liberation. Having attained liberation, the impermanent body of the buddhas, the world-honored ones, would then be the view of annihilation;
If the energy of the afflictions is always not extinguished, the buddhas, the world-honored ones, would then be the view of permanence.
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, definitely do not have these two views of annihilation and permanence.
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, have already severed these two views for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas.
If the TathÄgata had the notion of sentient beings, then he would be impermanent;
The TathÄgata has already severed the notion of sentient beings for immeasurable kalpas. If one says the TathÄgata has the notion of sentient beings, this is impossible.
Good son!

It is like a great king who comes and goes on excursions. When he is outside, those inside do not see him. Although those inside do not see him, one cannot say he does not exist. It is the same outside.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwelling in this samÄdhi have already severed impermanence. For the sake of sentient beings, they take on an impermanent body.
If one says:
'The TathÄgata's body is impermanent,' this is impossible.
Therefore, I say permanence and impermanence, self and no-self, sentient beings and non-sentient beings, humans and non-humans, life and non-life, and person and non-person.
The TathÄgata always says:
'All conditioned dharmas are impermanent.
' One should never say they are permanent, for if one says they are permanent, that is not correct.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who abide in this samÄdhi can then eliminate worldly views, views of life, and views of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas;
They have no craving, no grasping, no seeking;
They are always unchanging, accomplished, and abiding, and attain fearlessness;
They have no arrogance, and defilements cannot stain them.
Therefore I say 'permanence, bliss, self, and purity.'
Good man!
I say that the Å›rÄvaka and pratyekabuddha vehicles are not understood by all worldly people. Although worldly people do not understand, one still cannot say that the wise are the same.
Although worldly people see the TathÄgata as impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity, one still cannot say that those with wisdom have the same view as them.
Those with little blessings, dull faculties, and who practice wrong paths, say:
'The Tathagata is impermanent and eternally extinguished in nirvana.'
If one says the Tathagata is eternally extinguished, one should know that person is not free from the three evil paths.
Good son!
It is like a deep pond whose water is turbid, and within it there is a precious pearl that people cannot see.
Someone proclaims:
'In this turbid water there is a great precious pearl!'
When the people hear this, they compete to search for it, and some find tiles, stones, sand, gravel, and grass, but none can obtain the true treasure.
Because they cannot obtain it, they say it is false.
There is another person who is skilled in methods and places a priceless pearl in the turbid water, and the water immediately becomes clear, and the people then all see the true treasure.
Good son!
The sravakas and pratyekabuddhas do not understand the power of this samadhi, and therefore say:
'The TathÄgata is impermanent, without bliss, without self, and impure, empty and nonexistent.'
Not knowing that the TathÄgata is eternally unchanging, they revolve in birth and death.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwelling in this samÄdhi skillfully understand the TathÄgata's secret words. Therefore, this priceless jewel is used as a metaphor for samÄdhi.
Good man!
If men or women wish to see the TathÄgata's eternal constancy and immutability, they should cultivate such a samÄdhi.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwelling in this samÄdhi will see the TathÄgata's eternal constancy and immutability, and liberation is also like this.
Good man!
It is like the shade of a tree, where travelers can rest. Bodhisattvas dwelling in this samÄdhi are also like this, providing shade and shelter for all sentient beings.
Good man!
If there are people who say that the TathÄgata is impermanent and eternally in nirvÄá¹‡a, they are the disciples of MÄra;
If it were not so, they would be true disciples of mine.

If someone says that the TathÄgata will finally enter nirvÄá¹‡a, you should know that such a person defiles and insults my Dharma. If there are those who believe and accept such words, they are to be greatly pitied.

When these words were spoken, a great light emerged from the right side of the assembly. The light was golden in color and illuminated the trichiliocosm, completely obscuring the light of the sun, moon, and BrahmÄ, only unable to obscure the Buddha's radiance. The remaining lights became dim and did not appear.
The great and small Mount Sumerus, grasses, trees, and thickets, and the dark places between the two countries were all greatly illuminated.
The beings in the hells, upon encountering this light, had their suffering and pain cease, and their bodies attained peace and bliss.

At that time, in front of the entire great assembly, sixty koá¹­Ä«s of nayutas of lotus flowers suddenly appeared. The flowers were exquisite, with perfect color and fragrance, fully blooming with a thousand petals, and made of the four treasures.
Each lotus emits a subtle fragrance that pervades the trichiliocosm.

All the devas, nÄgas, ghosts, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, Åšakra, BrahmÄ, MÄra, devas, Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and all beings in the world, upon smelling this fragrance, all attain the love of the Dharma, delight in the MahÄyÄna, delight in listening to the Dharma, and eliminate all afflictions. This flower possesses such subtle and wonderful fragrance.

At that time, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Great Cloud Secret Treasury, in the great assembly, saw this spiritual transformation, immediately rose from his seat, joined his palms in respect, and addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
What are these appearances?
Whose virtuous power is this?
In this great assembly, there are these wonderful flowers emitting immeasurable fragrance?
Then, the celestial maiden Pure Light said to the bodhisattva Great Cloud Secret Treasury:
Good man!
All dharmas are completely without characteristics. Why do you ask:
'What are their characteristics and appearances?'
Dharmas are like dreams. Why do you ask in a way that is contrary to this, like one who is insane?
MahÄmegha-garbha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Celestial maiden!
I am not seeing dharmas as dreams, but in order to cut off attachment to characteristics, I ask this.
The celestial maiden said:
Venerable One!
Why do you see attachment to characteristics and give rise to this question?
Celestial maiden!
Therefore, I said earlier:
'For the sake of sentient beings, wishing to liberate them, therefore I ask.'
Venerable One!
If one does not personally cut off one's own views and doubts, how can one liberate sentient beings?
If one does not personally cut off one's own views and doubts, wishing to eliminate the views and doubts of sentient beings, this is impossible.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
It is just as the heavenly maiden has proclaimed.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who abide in this samÄdhi only see the signless.
Good man!
If men or women wish to see the signless, they should diligently cultivate this samÄdhi.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who abide in this samÄdhi can manifest various bodies in the trichiliocosm.
World-Honored One!
How can bodhisattvas abiding in this samÄdhi manifest various bodies in the trichiliocosm?
Good man!

If there is a magician or the disciple of a magician who, in a great assembly, can create various things such as men and women, large and small, birth and death, going and coming, houses and forests, elephants and horses, severed and broken, destroyed and ruined, continuous and interrupted,
The great assembly, upon seeing this, did not give rise to any shock or surprise.
Why is it so?
Because they understood it to be an illusion.
In the same way, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, abiding in this samÄdhi, cultivate the right path and transform various bodies throughout this trichiliocosm in order to liberate sentient beings.
The bodhisattvas abiding in this samÄdhi, upon seeing these transformations, do not give rise to shock or surprise, have no doubts, accord with the meaning, and do not go against it.
Why is it so?
Because they definitely know that it is the power of the samÄdhi.
